name: Cork
fun_fact: Fun fact: The English Market has been Cork's food hub since 1788, making it one of the oldest municipal markets in the world! Celebrity chef Rick Stein called it 'the best covered market in the UK and Ireland.'

hero_dishes.name: Drisheen and Tripe
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Cork blood sausage (drisheen) and tripe - authentic, old-school Irish fare that represents Cork's culinary heritage
hero_dishes.origin_story: These traditional Cork foods have been sold in the English Market since the 18th century, representing the city's working-class food traditions and nose-to-tail eating philosophy
hero_dishes.where_to_find: English Market (the traditional source since 1788), still available at market stalls alongside modern artisan products

hero_dishes.name: Spiced Beef
hero_dishes.description: Cork's signature cured beef, heavily spiced and traditionally served during Christmas but available year-round
hero_dishes.origin_story: A uniquely Cork tradition dating back centuries, this spiced and salted beef reflects the city's historic role as a provisioning port
hero_dishes.where_to_find: English Market vendors, traditional butchers throughout Cork city

hero_dishes.name: Frank Hederman's Smoked Salmon
hero_dishes.description: Expertly crafted smoked salmon from one of Ireland's most renowned fish smokers
hero_dishes.origin_story: Frank Hederman Smokehouse represents Cork's coastal heritage and modern artisan food movement. The city's location on the River Lee estuary provides access to exceptional seafood.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: English Market stalls, Frank Hederman Smokehouse (one of Ireland's most renowned smokehouses)

hero_dishes.name: Toonsbridge Dairy Cheeses
hero_dishes.description: Award-winning artisan cheeses from Cork's renowned cheesemaking tradition
hero_dishes.origin_story: Cork is home to some of Ireland's best-known cheesemakers including Carrigaline Farmhouse Cheese, Durrus Cheese, Gubbeen, and Coolea. The lush countryside provides ideal conditions for dairy farming.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: English Market (The Real Olive Company's stall and other vendors), Toonsbridge Dairy, artisan cheese shops throughout Cork

hero_dishes.name: CafÃ© Paradiso Vegetarian Cuisine
hero_dishes.description: Innovative vegetarian dishes showcasing local farm produce with spontaneous, seasonal menus
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Dennis Cotter put Cork vegetarian cuisine on the map at one of Europe's best vegetarian restaurants, sourcing from farms just outside the city
hero_dishes.where_to_find: CafÃ© Paradiso (one of the best vegetarian restaurants in Europe)

signature_drinks.name: Irish Whiskey and Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Cork's pub culture celebrates Irish whiskey and locally brewed craft beers
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in traditional pubs throughout the city, often paired with hearty Irish food

signature_drinks.name: Irish Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Coffee with Irish whiskey, sugar, and cream - perfect for Cork's rainy days
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A warming drink enjoyed in cafÃ©s and restaurants, especially after exploring the English Market

food_culture_notes: Cork is known as the food capital of Ireland - spearheaded the Irish food revolution
English Market opened in 1788, one of the oldest municipal markets in the world
Phenomenal range of produce from artisan cheese to smoked fish
Eight Michelin Guide restaurants including four with one star and one with two stars
Myrtle Allen was Ireland's first female Michelin-star chef, legacy continues with Darina Allen (Ballymaloe Cookery School) and Rachel Allen
Blessed with lush countryside for dairy and livestock plus rich seafood from coastal location
Age-old traditions and new thinking create a food-centered way of life
Cast of creative chefs under watchful eye of Cork's food community
English Market has quality meats, fish, herbs, spices, fruit, vegetables, baked goods, specialty cheeses
Traditional fare includes buttered eggs, battlebord (dried salted ling - member of cod family)

landmarks: Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral - Gothic Revival with three spiky spires, 1,260+ sculptures, built 1865-1879
English Market - Victorian covered market with ornate ironwork and fountain
River Lee flowing through the city center
Blackrock Castle on the banks of the River Lee
atmosphere: Bustling English Market with sensory feast of fresh produce and local delicacies
Peaceful cathedral with stained glass and Bath stone walls
Intimate artisan food shops and creative restaurants
Historic quarter showing Cork's heritage and culture
Ballymaloe Cookery School tradition of food education
Friendly food community with shared culinary pride
colors: Warm golden light in English Market
Rich greens of Irish countryside and River Lee
Creamy whites and yellows of artisan cheeses
Grey Gothic stonework of Saint Fin Barre's with colorful stained glass
Earthy browns of traditional spiced beef
unique_modern: English Market blends 1788 heritage with modern artisan food movement
Michelin-starred restaurants alongside traditional market stalls
Best-known cheesemakers creating international award winners
Renowned fish smokers using traditional techniques
Rick Stein's endorsement putting Cork on international food map
Cooking schools and food tours celebrating Cork culinary heritage
